1.0  Introduction
This Risk Management Plan (RMP) is part of the SI Group, Inc. (SI Group) continuing commitment to minimize the potential impact from our facility on our workers, our community neighbors, or the environment.  It is the stated policy of Addivant to safely manage our site operations.  In addition, we have prepared contingency plans to be used in the unlikely event that a major accident should occur.  The Morgantown, West Virginia facility is a certified Responsible Care facility.  Responsible Care is a technical standard for management of Environmental, Health, Safety and Security risks associated with our operations.  
We believe it is important for all interested parties to have access to information that can help them better understand our business and our facility.  If you have any questions about this document, or any other aspect of our company or our plans, please contact our Environmental Health, Safety and Security Manager at (304) 284-2214.
2.0  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Our company is committed to operating safe and environmentally sound chemical production facilities everywhere we do business.  Protection of our neighbors and workers is the highest priority.  This ongoing commitment to worker and public safety is demonstrated through resources invested for safe design, operation, and maintenance of our facilities.
In order to provide top quality products for our customers, the SI Group Morgantown facility utilizes certain raw materials in its manufacturing processes that are classified as toxic or flammable.  We are committed to comply with governing laws, regulations, and engineering standards as well as systematic assessments to manage and maintain a safe operation.  Our operating practices and procedures ensure that numerous controls are implemented to prevent an accidental release of a chemical.  However, if a major release does occur, our trained on-site emergency response team will be activate

d.  
3.0  Description of the Facility and Regulated Substances
SI Group currently operates two facilities, both of which are located in the Morgantown Industrial Park in Morgantown (Westover), West Virginia.  The facilities are referred to as the North Plant and the South Plant.  Both plants were built in 1965 and currently employ about 120 people in the Morgantown area.  Addivant manufactures millions of pounds of antioxidant chemicals marketed under trade names such as ULTRANOX(R), WESTON(R), and others.  Our products are used in various plastics, inks, coatings, and adhesives for improved ultraviolet (UV) heat, color, and processing stability.
This site is also home to a Technology Center, where SI Group conducts advanced research in specialty chemical technology.
4.0  Hazard Assessment Results
As part of our risk management planning, we have specifically identified the type of event that, should it ever occur, would have the most negative impacts on our workers and our neighbors.  This is known as the Worst-Case Scenario (WCS).  As defined by EPA, we are required to assume that the numerous engineering and administrative safety controls we have in place to prevent or mitigate such accidents have all failed at once.  EPA defines a worst-case scenario as a catastrophic failure, which is an event that essentially results in the instantaneous release of the contents in the largest single vessel on-site of a regulated RMP chemical.
A worst-case and alternative release scenario were developed for the North and South Plants using the RMP Comp software and ALOHA software.  The scenarios predicted the endpoint for each release scenario based upon the data input.
5.0  General Accidental Release Prevention/Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
SI Group has implemented a comprehensive program to prevent accidental releases of highly hazardous chemicals known as Process Safety Management (PSM).  PSM is an integral part of working safety at both the facilities.  PSM ensu

equipment needed to respond to on-site emergencies.  Our response team works with area hospitals, industries, and other response organizations in the Monongalia County area.  For example, past emergency drills, organized and directed by SI Group emergency teams, have included:
-A simulated liquid waste incident completed in September 1996 with Monongalia County Emergency officials, and police departments from the City of Westover, West Virginia; 
-A simulated chemical tanker truck incident with Monongalia County Emergency services conducted during January 1997; 
-A simulated phosphorus trichloride incident and community-wide drill with the Westover Volunteer Fire Department, Monongalia Emergency Services and area hospitals during June 1998. 
-Participated in the Morgantown Mock Disaster Drill, West Virginia Regional Response Team in October 2002. 
-Completed onsite drill in 2008 with plant emergency response team and medical team simulating spill/release.
-Completed training with City of Westover Volunteer Fire Department on two separate occasions in 2008.
-Facility completes quarterly headcount drills
-Hosted monthly meeting with members of the Local Emergency Planning Committee May 2009.
Ongoing training exercises are important to the company's emergency response organization and help better prepare our partners in the community for emergency response necessary in the unlikely event of a major industrial incident.
Information about how to shelter yourself and your family in the event of a chemical emergency can be found in the local telephone directory and on the Monongalia County Office of Emergency Management's web page at http://www.moncooem.org/. 
SI Group personnel have helped develop emergency preparedness plans for local communities.  In addition, they are members of local emergency planning and emergency preparedness groups.  As consistent with the Monongalia County Emergency Response Plan, SI Group will work through the Monongalia County Emerge

ncy Management Commission to communicate any appropriate actions to be taken by the public in the event of a chemical emergency.
8.0  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
SI Group is committed to continuously improving the overall safety and environmental performance record at the Morgantown site.  Some of the specific planned changes aimed at improving safety are:
-Continuing development of best management practices under OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM);
-Implementing additional training programs for employees to further reduce the chance of human error leading to a workplace injury or an accidental release; 
-Continuing active involvement in the Local Emergency Planning Committee and support emergency preparedness programs; and
-Continuing implementation of Mutual Aid Agreements with various City of Westover and Monongalia County Emergency Management Services.
